image.altText: A bright sunset paints the sky orange as the Sydney Opera House is seen below.

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology formally declares an El Niño weather event, months after the World Meteorological Organization announced the same. Follow live.

title.children: Bureau of Meteorology formally declares El Niño weather event as hot and dry conditions sweep south-east Australia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Craig: Does the recent and protracted La Niña period mean there'll be an equally protracted El Niño period? Here's ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders: The recent three-year La Niña does not increase the risk of a multi-year El Niño. Most El Niño's only last one year (6-9 months to be precise), but very occasionally can last two to three years.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the El Niño be longer than normal?

children.content: Craig:
Does the recent and protracted La Niña period mean there'll be an equally protracted El Niño period?
Here's ABC meteorologist Tom
Saunders:
The recent three-year La Niña does not increase the risk of a multi-year El Niño.
Most El Niño's only last one year (6-9 months to be precise), but very occasionally can last two to three years.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: CJJ93: Does the El Niño include WA or just the eastern states? Here's ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders: The correct question would be, "does El Nino impact WA"? The answer for the most part is no, but a Positive IOD has also developed and this does impact WA. So expect a warm and dry finish to 2023.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will an El Niño affect Western Australia?

children.content: CJJ93:
Does the El Niño include WA or just the eastern states?
Here's ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders:
The correct question would be, "does El Nino impact WA"?
The answer for the most part is no, but a Positive IOD has also developed and this does impact WA.
So expect a warm and dry finish to 2023.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rob: Is a reef bleaching event more likely with an El Niño? Here's ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders: No, because often El Niño sees cooler waters off the northern coast of Australia. However global warming is making everywhere warm right now so a bleaching event wouldn't be a surprise even with El Niño.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What does it mean for our reefs?

children.content: Rob:
Is a reef bleaching event more likely with an El Niño?
Here's ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders:
No, because often El Niño sees cooler waters off the northern coast of Australia.
However global warming is making everywhere warm right now so a bleaching event wouldn't be a surprise even with El Niño.

image.altText: Sunset over water

props.synopsis: One of the world's most consequential climate drivers, El Niño, is underway for the first time in eight years, according to Australia's Bureau of Meteorology.

title.children: BOM officially declares El Niño, warns Australians to prepare for summer of extreme heatwaves

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wearing a black hoodie with the "yes" logo on the front.

props.synopsis: Supporters of the Voice to Parliament, including Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and SA Premier Peter Malinauskas have called out protesters who targeted a major No campaign event in Adelaide.

title.children: Prime Minister calls for 'respectful' debate after protesters target No campaign event

image.altText: A man wearing a wide-brimmed hat and glasses, smiles for a photo as he holds aloft a fish.

props.synopsis: A man has gone on trial in Adelaide's Supreme Court accused of murdering a 70-year-old driver during a road rage altercation in the CBD last year.

title.children: Road rage murder accused stands trial over death of older man in CBD dispute

image.altText: A butcher smiles.

props.synopsis: South Australian businesses say they're rethinking how they run their services, with the most recent round of power price hikes already taking a significant toll on customers who are cutting back on purchases.

title.children: 'Everything is going up': Small businesses struggle to keep clients as prices rise

image.altText: Ceduna jetty at sunset

props.synopsis: South Australia regional towns of Ceduna and Port Augusta have broken September hot weather records this week in a worrying sign of warmer-than-average temperatures to come this summer.

title.children: Hot weather warning as SA towns smash heat records

image.altText: The remains of dozens of trees lay on the ground as a sign warns people the area is restricted

props.synopsis: This suburban park in Adelaide's north-east used to resemble a small forest, filled with hundreds of well-established pine trees — but it has been left decimated thanks to an exotic pest.

title.children: What is the exotic pest threatening Australia's plantation industry?

image.altText: A relaxed young man wears an open-collared shirt and looks left of the camera, a lamp and door behind him are out of focus

props.synopsis: When Senator Steele-John became the youngest-ever senator, he put his new paycheque toward removing "that knot of fear in the stomach" that came with his family's debt.

title.children: Jordon Steele-John on how paying down his family's debt was a 'privilege'

image.altText: A man stares down the barrel of a camera while sitting in a room, wearing all black.

props.synopsis: Twenty-four-year-old Alex Ophel makes a brief appearance in court, charged with two counts of attempted murder, two counts of assault and one count of possessing an object to be used to kill.

title.children: Man charged with attempted murder over stabbing of two female students at ANU

image.altText: A woman smiles.

props.synopsis: Tilda Cobham-Hervey is set to end a seven-year break from the stage, confident that her role in an adaption of international bestselling novel The Dictionary Of Lost Words will wow audiences.

title.children: Australian film star to take lead role in stage production of bestselling novel

image.altText: Qatar Airways and Qantas planes on tarmac in Perth.

props.synopsis: The lawyer representing Australian women subjected to invasive body searches at Doha airport say they're worried there is an ongoing risk to women flying Qatar Airways.

title.children: Women strip searched at Qatari airport fear similar incident could happen again

image.altText: A photo of a large orange painting of a harbour with palm trees at the bottom, a pier at the top and boats in the water

props.synopsis: In 2007, a gallery assistant made a discovery that rocked the Australian art world and led to one of the most controversial, high-profile and enduring art mysteries.

title.children: How one of Australia's most controversial art mysteries unfolded

image.altText: A search and rescue worker in burnt Lahaina

props.synopsis: As Australia experiences "bigger … hotter fires", experts say buffel grass — which is now found in every state and territory — poses a growing bushfire risk.

title.children: Invasive grass with role in deadly Maui blaze 'absolutely a threat' to Australian lives

image.altText: Bishop of Broome Christopher Saunders in front of pearl shell alter in the Beagle Bay church.

props.synopsis: 'Deeply distressing' allegations have been levelled against long-serving Broome Bishop Christopher Saunders, including sexually assaulting young males.

title.children: Long-serving Catholic Bishop faces allegations of 'very serious' sexual abuse in Vatican report

image.altText: Fire trucks parked on the side of a road, with bushland to the left.

props.synopsis: The fire danger warning for the NSW Far South Coast is upgraded to catastrophic and several fires are burning at Watch and Act level as the state faces a day of hot and windy weather.

title.children: Far South Coast fire danger upgraded to catastrophic as schools close, hot and windy conditions persist

image.altText: a person in an Akubra hat silhouetted against an Indigenous flag

props.synopsis: A far-right US media figure who has made racist attacks on Indigenous Australians spoke at a conservative conference chaired by leading No campaigner Warren Mundine.

title.children: Far-right US podcaster spoke at conservative conference chaired by Warren Mundine

image.altText: Police seize massive cannabis crop near Gympie in Queensland

props.synopsis: Around 1.2 tonnes of methamphetamine, MDMA and cannabis are seized across Australia and hundreds of people are arrested during Operation Vitreus, a joint police initiative targeting organised crime.

title.children: Almost 1,000 people arrested, $475m of drugs seized in nationwide crackdown on organised crime

image.altText: a close-up of a person's hand holding a chicken and salad sandwich made with white bread

props.synopsis: Listeria is an opportunistic infection so not everyone will get sick if they eat food with the bacteria. But it's particularly problematic for pregnant women, the elderly and people with chronic illness.

title.children: Listeria outbreak recorded in three states. Here are some ways you can avoid it

image.altText: A man and woman sit next to each other smiling

props.synopsis: Trisha Stratford, a relationship expert on the first seven seasons of the popular reality series Married at First Sight Australia, has died aged 72.

title.children: 'We all loved her': Former Married at First Sight relationship expert Trisha Stratford dies aged 72

image.altText: A couple has their wedding photograph taken underwater.

props.synopsis: A plunge in the number of Chinese couples willing to tie the knot is hurting the marriage industry and worrying officials trying to revive marriage and birth rates.

title.children: 'Some of my clients have actually separated': Marriage woes hit once-lavish Chinese wedding industry

image.altText: The Google app displayed on a smartphone, next to the US flag outside a Department of Justice building.

props.synopsis: The US government has told a federal court that Google has exploited its position as "the gatekeeper of the internet" to destroy competition.

title.children: The US has taken Google to court for allegedly rigging the internet search market. Here's what has happened so far

image.altText: A wide shot of the empty Reserve Bank of Australia boardroom.

props.synopsis: The increasing cost of petrol could complicate the Reserve Bank's attempts to get inflation down, board minutes shows.

title.children: RBA can't rule out another rate rise this year, amid rising petrol prices

image.altText: woman runs in shade on Sydney beach

props.synopsis: A record spell of September heat is baking southern states, with temperatures as much as 18 degrees Celsius above average.

title.children: A cool change is coming to south-eastern Australia — but it will get even hotter first

image.altText: A hand holding a fuel nozzle putting petrol in a white car

props.synopsis: People are feeling the pinch around the country as national average petrol prices top 204.4 cents per litre. But where are you at in the price cycle?

title.children: With school holidays imminent for some, will petrol prices drop any time soon? Your capital city breakdown

image.altText: man showing younger man how to connect devices to a battery, in workshop with Forklift in the background

props.synopsis: It's not so easy to tinker under the bonnet of the family car anymore so the next generation is gaining skills in electronics in new-look careers.

title.children: Mechanical apprentices pivot to keep up with electric vehicles, autonomous tractors

image.altText: Russell Brand

props.synopsis: They're allegations even the most beloved of Hollywood A-Listers would struggle to explain away, but Russell Brand and his millions of online followers exist in a different dimension, far away from cancel culture.

title.children: It's too late to cancel Russell Brand — he did it himself a decade ago

image.altText: Russell Brand leaves the Troubabour Wembley Park theatre. He is wearing sunglasses at night.

props.synopsis: A woman who accused British actor and comedian Russell Brand of sexual and emotional abuse says his denial of the allegations is "insulting".

title.children: 'Laughable and insulting': Russell Brand accuser hits out at his denials in fresh interview

image.altText: Hundreds of people all packed in together with their arms up.

props.synopsis: A minister in the eastern Libyan government said Mr Ghaithi has been suspended from his post.

title.children: Protesters set fire to ex-mayor Abdulmenam al-Ghaithi's house following deadly floods

image.altText: The cast of Heartbreak High pose on set in colourful outfits.

props.synopsis: Australian screenwriters and actors say our local industry provides a worrying blueprint for their US counterparts, as a reckoning over royalties and writer's rooms begins to brew here.

title.children: The US screen industry is facing an existential crisis. Is Australia next?

image.altText: Tactical police officer attends the scene of a police stand off.

props.synopsis: Police say a bean-bag round entered the body of Newcastle woman Krista Kach, who was involved in a stand-off with police in Stockton last week.

title.children: Police suspend use of bean-bag rounds after woman killed by strike to the heart

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a blank canvas

props.synopsis: The museum believed artist Jens Haaning was planning to embed banknotes in two glass frames — instead it got back empty canvases.

title.children: 'Take the Money and Run': Danish artist told to return almost $112k after giving gallery blank canvases

image.altText: man in suit rubbing hands together next to logo of a white x on black background

props.synopsis: X/Twitter owner Elon Musk says his social media company plans to start charging a small monthly payment to use the platform. Meanwhile, the ASX is in the red and the Reserve Bank discussed raising rates earlier this month before keeping them on hold. Follow live.

title.children: Elon Musk says X/Twitter set to charge users, ASX falls, Reserve Bank considered a September rate hike

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You may have noticed that prices at the petrol pump have climbed above $2 a litre in recent weeks because of higher global oil prices. While prices are still below last year's highs, which were well above $US100 a barrel after Russia invaded Ukraine, the higher cost of fuel is weighing on household budgets and contributing to inflation. The main reason for the price rises is that the oil producers cartel, OPEC, has limited production to bolster prices because they are worried about the slowing global economy reducing demand for fuel. Saudi Arabia and Russia, the two biggest producers in the OPEC+ group have extended their production cuts, and that's got investors worried about a supply deficit over the last quarter of the year. My colleague Nassim Khadem has written this excellent analysis on why OPEC is important.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil at highest level this year above $US90 a barrel

featuredLink.title: '$4.7b in profits a day': A powerful cartel still controls the world's oil and is why you're paying more for petrol

children.content: You may have noticed that prices at the petrol pump have climbed above $2 a litre in recent weeks because of higher global oil prices.

While prices are still below last year's highs, which were well above $US100 a barrel after Russia invaded Ukraine, the higher cost of fuel is weighing on household budgets and contributing to inflation.

The main reason for the price rises is that the oil producers cartel, OPEC, has limited production to bolster prices because they are worried about the slowing global economy reducing demand for fuel.
Saudi Arabia and Russia, the two biggest producers in the OPEC+ group have extended their production cuts, and that's got investors worried about a supply deficit over the last quarter of the year.
My colleague Nassim Khadem has written this excellent analysis on why OPEC is important.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's check in with the Australian share market. Weaker iron ore prices are weighing on the big miners, and big banks are weaker ahead of this week's meeting by the US Federal Reserve. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates on hold. The ASX 200 index is down 0.4 per cent in afternoon trade. Explosives maker Orica (+1.5 per cent) is higher after it announced higher pollution reduction targets at its Sustainability Investor Day. These include: an increased target to reduce direct carbon emissions (Scope 1 & 2) by at least 45 per cent by 2030 from 2019 levels a new short term target to reduce direct emissions by 30 per cent by 2026 from 2019 levels a new ambition to reduce customer and supply chain emissions (Scope 3) by 25 per cent by 2035 from 2022 baseline levels. Orica also confirmed its profit predictions for the full year. Takeover target Newcrest Mining (+1.5 per cent) gained after the world's biggest gold miner Newmont Mining got the green light from the Foreign Investment Review Board to buy the local gold producer for $26.2 billion. More regulatory approvals are required including a vote by shareholders. Logistics company Qube (-1 per cent) fell after reporting the death of a worker following at incident at its forestry harvesting operations in South Australia. SafeWork SA and the state police are investigating.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red but off its lows

children.content: Let's check in with the Australian share market.
Weaker iron ore prices
are weighing on the big miners, and big banks are weaker ahead of this week's meeting by the US Federal Reserve.
The Fed is expected to keep interest rates on hold.
The ASX 200 index is down 0.4 per cent in afternoon trade.
Explosives maker Orica (+1.5 per cent)
is higher after it announced higher pollution reduction targets at its Sustainability Investor Day.
These include:
an increased target to reduce direct carbon emissions (Scope 1
by at least 45 per cent by 2030 from 2019 levels
a new short term target to reduce direct emissions by 30 per cent by 2026 from 2019 levels
a new ambition to reduce customer and supply chain emissions (Scope 3) by 25 per cent by 2035 from 2022 baseline levels.
Orica also confirmed its profit predictions for the full
year.
Takeover target
Newcrest Mining
(+1.5 per cent) gained after the world's biggest gold miner
Newmont Mining
got the green light from the Foreign Investment Review Board to buy the local gold producer for $26.2 billion.
More regulatory approvals are required including a vote by shareholders.
Logistics company
Qube
(-1 per cent) fell after reporting the death of a worker following at incident at its forestry harvesting operations in South Australia.
SafeWork SA and the state police are investigating.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And here's some of the signs of the slowing economy as consumer spend less because of higher borrowing costs bite. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry-Westpac Survey of Industrial Trends. Australia's longest running business survey, remained at low levels over the third quarter, just above 50 points, which is the break even mark. Westpac says manufacturers are facing the weakest demand (outside of the pandemic) in a decade, and declining profitability. The survey of firms found new orders were flat for a second quarter, and employment and overtime fell. In fact, new orders, which are a key sign of health for a business because they indicate current demand, are the weakest for the half year since 2013. "The key message and the number one concern of manufacturers is the lack of any growth in new orders." "Back-to-back flat new orders (with only a net 1 per cent reporting a rise for both June and September quarters) is consistent with the marked slowing of the Australian economy." "The economic downturn is centred on consumer spending, which was flat in the June quarter, as household real disposable income contracted for a fifth consecutive quarter, squeezed by rising living costs, higher interest rates, and additional tax obligations." The survey found the general business mood remains deeply pessimistic. More than one third of respondents expect the general business situation to worsen over the next six months, little changed from the previous quarter. So looks like AMP's Diana Mousina could be right when she says 50:50 chance of a recession. On the upside, Westpac says production rose modestly helped by an easing of worker and material shortages. And it thinks the survey suggests that the RBA is on hold from here. "Inflation pressures have eased the survey finds, which along with the soft demand backdrop, adds to the case for the RBA remaining on hold and suggest that official interest rates have likely peaked."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Manufacturers face lowest demand in a decade

over the third quarter, just above 50 points, which is the break even mark.

The survey of firms found new orders were flat for a second quarter, and employment and overtime fell.

(ACCI-Westpac)
In fact, new orders, which are a key sign of health for a business because they indicate current demand, are the weakest for the half year since 2013.
"The key message and the number one concern of manufacturers is the lack of any growth in new orders."
"Back-to-back flat new orders (with only a net 1 per cent reporting a rise for both June and September quarters) is consistent with the marked slowing of the Australian economy."
"The economic downturn is centred on consumer spending, which was flat in the June quarter, as household real disposable income contracted for a fifth consecutive quarter, squeezed
by rising living costs, higher interest rates, and additional tax obligations."
The survey found the general business mood remains deeply pessimistic.
More than one third of respondents expect the general business situation to worsen over the next six months, little changed from
the previous quarter.
So looks like AMP's Diana Mousina could be right when she says
50:50 chance of a recession.
On the upside, Westpac says production rose modestly helped by an easing of worker and material shortages.
And it thinks the survey suggests that the RBA is on hold from here.

"Inflation pressures have eased the survey finds, which along with the soft demand backdrop, adds to the case for the RBA remaining on hold and suggest that official interest rates have likely peaked."

image.altText: Zelenskyy stands with a soldier for a photo.

props.synopsis: Speaking ahead of addressing the United Nations General Assembly, Volodymyr Zelenskyy says it is important for Ukraine's message "to be heard" and members must ask themselves if the organisation still has "a place for Russian terrorists".

title.children: Zelenskyy visits wounded Ukrainian soldiers in New York ahead of UN speech
